I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to the Republic of Azerbaijan for the Second Road Network 
Development Investment Program (the investment program).1 
 

II. 

THE INVESTMENT PROGRAM 

A. 

Rationale 

2. 
The investment program will construct an approximately 63 km section of the motorway 
between Masalli and Shorsulu, along the South–North corridor of the country. It also includes a 
nonphysical  investment  component  for  road  safety  improvement  and  capacity  development. 
The  investment  program  is  a  government  priority  and  is  included  in  the  Asian  Development 
Bank’s (ADB) country operations business plan for Azerbaijan for 2012–2014. 
 
The  transport  sector  plays  an  important  role  in  Azerbaijan’s  economy,  accounting  for 
3. 
about  6%  of  the  gross  domestic  product  (GDP).  Roads  are  the  dominant  mode  of  freight  and 
passenger transport. The country occupies an important geographical position for transit routes 
with roads and railway lines connecting the Black Sea and the Caspian Sea. Thus, the transport 
sector contributes to regional cooperation by facilitating the development of international trade. 
The  sector  is  also crucial  to  the  domestic  economy  since  it  links  the  rural  population  to  urban 
and international markets. 
 
The  development  of  transport  infrastructure  is  one  of  the  government’s  key  tasks  to 
4. 
sustain  GDP  growth  and  promote  trade  with  neighboring  countries.  The  poor  condition  of  the 
national  road  network  poses  a  challenge.  About  56%  of  the  main  road  network  is  in  poor 
condition  and  needs  urgent  repair;  most  of  the  lower  category  roads  are  in  extremely  bad 
shape. The  East–West corridor (Baku–Ganja–Georgia border through Alyat  and a more  direct 
route  through  Shamakhi)  and  the  North–South  corridor  (Russian  Federation  border–Baku–
Alyat–Iran  border),  as  well  as feeder  roads  connecting rural  areas  and  the main corridors,  are 
crucial to addressing the transport bottlenecks to national development and poverty reduction. 
 
5. 
The  road  subsector  in  Azerbaijan  faces  four  main  problems:  (i)  poor  road  conditions, 
(ii)  inadequate  program  delivery  because  of  weak  institutional  capacity,  (iii)  inadequate 
maintenance  of  roads,  and  (iv)  poor  quality  of  construction.  These  bottlenecks  lead  to  higher-
than-average  construction  and  maintenance  costs  and  delay  construction. 2
 While  the  ADB-
assisted road projects  have experienced delays and cost overruns, overall they have been built 
as designed.  Building  projects  on time,  within budget,  and to  high  standards  is  possible,  but  it 
requires effective and efficient program and project management. 
 
6. 
Strategic  context  and  road  map.  The  State  Program  on  Poverty  Reduction  and 
Economic  Development  (SPPRED),  2008–2015 3 and  the  State  Program  on  Socioeconomic 
Development  of  Regions,  2009–20144 represent  the  government’s  overall  strategic  framework 
for  development.  The  infrastructure  pillar  of  the  SPPRED  includes  reconstructing  a  significant 
portion of the country’s roads in accordance with international standards. To realize the strategic

goal for road reconstruction, the government prepared a Road Network Development Program 
(RNDP) 5 for  2006–2015,  which  was  subsequently  extended  to  2022.  Under  the  RNDP,  the 
reconstruction  and  rehabilitation  of  about  9,500  kilometers  (km)  of  roads  is  planned  during 
2006–2022  at  a  total  cost  of  about  $8.46  billion  (in  2012  prices).  Through  both  physical  and 
nonphysical interventions, the RNDP establishes a road map for the development of an efficient, 
safe,  sustainable,  and  internationally  and  domestically  integrated  transport  network  to  support 
the  country’s  economic  and  social  development.  A  new  MFF  is  needed  to  support  the 
government’s  new  priority  projects.  The  strategy  and  road  map  of  a  2007  MFF  for  road 
development have been updated and remain valid for this new MFF. The proposed investment 
program is in line with the overall transport sector development strategy of the government.6 
 
7. 
First  Road  Network  Development  Program.  In  September  2007,  ADB  approved  an 
MFF in the amount of $500 million equivalent for the first Road Network Development Program.7 
The program is ongoing with three tranches approved to date.  Project 1, supported by a $200 
million  loan,  is  for  the  construction  of  sections  of  the  Masalli–Astara  expressway.  Project  2 
($55.4  million  loan)  is  for  the  construction  of  the  Ganja  bypass.  Project  3  ($200  million  loan), 
also  for  the  construction  of  sections  of  the  Masalli–Astara  expressway,  was  approved  in 
December 2011. 
 
8. 
Project 1 experienced initial implementation delays because (i) the implementing agency 
lacked  the  expertise  to  comply  with  ADB’s  safeguard  requirements  regarding  land  acquisition 
and resettlement (LAR); and (ii) the construction period was not synchronized with the working 
season.  Project  costs  also  increased,  primarily  because of a sharp  rise  in the  cost  of fuel  and 
construction  materials,  and  the  failure  of  the  feasibility  study  to  account  for  certain  additional 
expenditures.  Since  land  acquisition  for  the  entire  project  road  could  not  be  completed  in  a 
timely manner, two sections of the project road were removed from the scope of project 1 and 
are  being  constructed  under  project  3.  With  continuous  ADB  monitoring  and  project 
management  support,  implementation  of  project  1  has  accelerated  and  is  targeted  for 
completion by the end of 2013.  
 
9. 
Project 2 did not have any LAR impacts, but the implementation progress has been slow 
due  to  (i)  the  late  mobilization  of  the  contractor,  (ii)  delayed  customs  clearance  for  imported 
equipment,  and (iii)  low  rate  of  civil  works  progress  by  the  contractor.  Through  joint  efforts  by 
ADB and the government, the civil works have been accelerating and will be completed by the 
end  of  2012.  Project  3,  which  is  undergoing  procurement,  is  targeted  for  completion  by 
December 2015. Like project 1, implementation of project 3 has been affected by increased cost 
estimates. Overall, the physical investment components under the first investment program are 
expected  to  be  completed  as  designed.8 The  study  on  development  of  legal  and  regulatory 
frameworks  and  operational  procedures  for  toll  roads  is  ongoing.  This  will  create  an  enabling 
environment for private sector participation in road construction, operation, and maintenance. 
 
                                                
5  The  Ministry  of  Transport  (MOT)  prepared  a  RNDP  for  2006–2015  in  July  2006  with  an  estimated  cost  of  
$5.3 billion (in 2006 prices). While the government undertook implementation of the road projects, implementation 
of  the  RNDP  was  slowed  by  delays  in  land  acquisition  and  resettlement,  lack  of  project  readiness,  delays  in 
procurement of works and consulting services, and lack of institutional capabilities. 

6  In support of implementing the SPPRED and other programs of the government, MOT prepared a transport policy 
paper, followed by a transport sector development strategy developed with ADB assistance:  ADB. 2006. Republic 
of Azerbaijan: Transport Sector Development Strategy. Baku. (Technical assistance consultant report). 

7  ADB.  2007.  Report  and  Recommendation  of  the  President  to  the  Board  of  Directors:  Proposed  Multitranche 

Financing Facility to the Republic of Azerbaijan for the Road Network Development Program. Manila. 

8  At the request of the executing agency, the balance of the MFF funding totaling $44.6 million is available for any 

new project meeting MFF criteria, or additional financing under tranches 1, 2, and 3, if required. 

 New  multitranche  financing  facility.  The  Alyat–Masalli  motorway,  which  is  a  priority 
10. 
project  under  the  government’s  RNDP,  was  originally  planned  for  implementation  under  a 
highway project financed by the World Bank. The World Bank dropped a road section of about 
63  km  (Masalli  to  Shorsulu)  for  its  financing,  primarily  because  of  cost  overruns  and  low 
disbursement  rates  in  its  ongoing  projects. 9  However,  the  World  Bank  had  carried  out 
preparatory  work  including  detailed  designs,  cost  estimates,  and  safeguard  documents. 
LAR activities have been substantially completed in accordance with World Bank requirements. 
Thus, given the level of project readiness, the government asked ADB to provide a new MFF to 
finance  the  construction  of  the  motorway  between  Masalli  and  Shorsulu.  ADB  has  carried  out 
due  diligence  on the World  Bank’s  preparatory  documents  and  confirms that  they  comply  with 
ADB policy requirements. 
 
The  proposed  investments—both  physical  and  nonphysical—will  add  to  those  being 
11. 
supported  by  ADB  and  other  development  partners  in  Azerbaijan.  Built  on  the  results  of  the 
ongoing first Road Network Development Program (footnote 7) and using a holistic approach to 
the road subsector, the new MFF will help make Azerbaijan’s road network more effective and 
efficient.  It  will  include  a  capacity  development  component  to  strengthen  the  capacity  of  the 
executing  and  implementing  agencies  through  training  in  planning,  project  preparation,  and 
project  implementation.  The  capacity  development  will  also  assist  the  executing  and 
implementing agencies in (i) mainstreaming road safety audits during the design, construction, 
including  prescribing  road  safety 
the  road  network, 
and 
improvements; (ii) developing road standards and specifications, including for pavement layers 
under  different  climatic  and  site  conditions;  and  (iii)  prioritizing  road  sections  for  long-term, 
performance-based maintenance contracts. 
 
12. 
The  government  has  selected  the  MFF  modality  to  finance  this  highway  section  based 
on the experience with the first MFF and to ensure continuity. The MFF is the suitable funding 
modality because of its flexibility and ability to sequence investments based on the readiness of 
the  program.  In  addition,  the  country  allocation  limit  would  not  allow  a  stand-alone  loan  large 
enough to finance the entire 63 km road section. All the preconditions for the MFF are in place, 
including  a  coherent  strategy,  sector  road  map,  investment  and  financing  plans,  and  policy 
framework.  Preparatory  work  for  the  road  section  has  been  completed  and  is  ready  for 
implementation  in  two  tranches.  Based  on  the  near-term  investment  requirements  of  the 
government,  the  proposed  new  MFF  will  cover  80%  of  the  estimated  cost  of  the  investment 
program.  This  will  consolidate  the  partnership  started  under  the  first  MFF.  Lessons  from  the 
implementation  of  the  first  Road  Network  Development  Program  and  from  World  Bank 
projects—such  as  cost  overruns,  slow  implementation,  and  low  disbursement  rates—were 
considered in designing the new MFF.  
 
B. 

implementation  phases  of 

Impact and Outcome 

13. 
The impact of the investment program will be greater economic growth in Azerbaijan and 
expanded  trade  with  neighboring  countries.  The  outcome  will  be  an  efficient,  adequate,  safe, 
and sustainable southern motorway corridor from Baku in Azerbaijan. 
 

                                                
9  The  World  Bank  provided  additional  financing  to  cover  cost  overruns,  but  not  enough  to  cover  this  section.  
In addition, the World Bank policy restricts additional investment, as the disbursement rate is below the minimum 
requirement. Hence, the World Bank cannot finance this section of the Alyat–Masalli motorway.

road  between  Jalilabad  and  Shorsulu,  a  section  of  the  Masalli–Shorsulu  motorway;  (ii)  further 
improved  program  and  project  management,  and  implementation  capacities  of  ARS;  and 
(iii)  improved  transport  sector  governance  through  mainstreaming  of  road  safety  audits  and 
improvements, development of road and pavement standards and guidelines, and development 
of performance-based maintenance contracts. 
 
D. 

Investment and Financing Plans 

1. 

Investment Plan 

16.

The new investment program will cost $625 million equivalent, with the cost of tranche 1 being

2. 

Financing Plan 

17. 
The government plans to finance the RNDP, 2006–2022 through a balance of domestic 
and foreign financing. Domestic sources include the road fund restored in 2007 to finance road 
subsector and budgetary allocation totaling about $2.6 billion. The government will also obtain 
financial assistance from multilateral and bilateral development partners, as well as commercial 
banks.10 
                                                
10 In addition to ADB, other external aid agencies that have expressed a willingness to support implementation of the 
RNDP  include  the  European  Bank  for  Reconstruction  and  Development  and  the  World  Bank  (about  $1  billion 
each), and commercial banks (about $1.3 billion). The government is still seeking  additional funding to cover the 
balance. 

 

 The government has requested an MFF in an amount up to $500 million equivalent from 
18. 
ADB's  ordinary  capital  resources  to  help finance  part  of  the  investment  program,  which  will  in 
turn support a portion of the RNDP, 2006–2022. The MFF will consist of two tranches, subject to 
the  government's  submission  of  related  periodic  financing  requests,  execution  of  the  related 
loan agreement for each tranche, and fulfillment of terms and conditions and undertakings set 
forth  in  the  framework  financing  agreement.  The  first  tranche  of  the  MFF  will  have  a  21-year 
term,  including  a  grace  period  of  4  years,  straight-line  repayment  method,  an  annual  interest 
rate determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending 
facility, a commitment charge of 0.15% per year, and such other terms and conditions set forth 
in  the  draft  loan  agreement.  Based  on  these  loan  terms  and  repayment  method,  the  average 
loan maturity is 12.75 years and there is no maturity premium payable to ADB. 
 
The financing plan is summarized in Table 2. The government’s contribution will be used 
19. 
to  meet  land  acquisition  costs,  taxes  and  duties,  and  interest  and  other  charges  during 
construction.

Implementation Arrangements 

E. 

20. 
The  Ministry  of  Transport  (MOT)  will  be  the  executing  agency  and  ARS  will  be  the 
implementing  agency.  To  administer  the  investment  program  effectively,  the  program  steering 
committee  chaired  by  a  deputy  minister  of  transport  to  oversee  the  implementation  of  the  first 
Road  Network  Development  Program  will  continue  to  provide  overall  guidance  for  the 
implementation of the new investment program. It will include representatives from the Cabinet 
of  Ministers,  Ministry  of  Economic  Development,  Ministry  of  Finance,  MOT,  ARS,  and  the 
director  of  the  project  implementation  unit  (PIU).  The  committee  will  meet  quarterly  to  monitor 
and  ensure  that  appropriate  measures  are  taken  for  the  timely  program  implementation. 
The committee will support interagency coordination to facilitate timely approvals. 
 
21. 
ARS will be responsible for daily implementation activities. ARS will expand the existing 
PIU  to  implement  the  investment  program.  Given  the  limited  technical  staff  in  the  PIU,  
a program management consultant will be engaged under tranche 1. Based on the consultant’s 
performance  under  tranche  1,  the  scope  of  the  contract  may  be  extended  to  cover  various 
studies on transport sector governance under tranche 2 and to assist ARS with implementation 
of  the  entire  investment  program.  The  consultant  will  also  build  the  capacity  of  ARS  and  PIU 
through  on-the-job  training  and  other  specialized  training.  These  may  include  integrating 
climate-proofing  measures  in  the  road  design,  procurement,  construction  monitoring  and 
maintenance,  environmental  and  social  safeguards,  financial  management,  and  contract  and 
project  management.  The  aim  is  to  enable  the  PIU  staff  to  handle  program  management 
independently  in  future.  Thus,  the  consultant’s  role  is  to  build,  not  to  substitute,  the  PIU’s 
capacity. The consultant will help ARS prepare project and program management reports to be 
submitted to MOT and ADB. 
 

5 

 

 6 

 

The program management consultant and the PIU will jointly oversee all activities during 
22. 
the implementation of the investment program, including project preparation and administration, 
procurement  of  works  and  consulting  services,  disbursements  and  financial  management, 
compliance  with  safeguard  requirements,  and  reporting  to  MOT  and  ADB.  The  consultant  will 
introduce  a  suitable  management  information  system  in  the  PIU  and  train  the  staff  to  achieve 
efficient and effective management of the investment program. The consultant will assist ARS in 
preparing and submitting flash reports and photographs concerning implementation progress of 
each  tranche.  The  consultant  will  also  submit  other  required  performance  and  monitoring 
reports  consistent  with  existing  project  implementation  requirements  and  compliance  with 
covenants. 
 
23. 
Procurement  of  works  financed  by  the  MFF  will  follow  ADB's  Procurement  Guidelines 
(2010,  as  amended from  time to time).  Consultant  recruitment  will  follow  ADB’s  Guidelines  on 
the  Use  of  Consultants  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  ADB  approved  advance 
contracting  of  works  and  consulting  services  under  the  investment  program  on  4  July  2012.

 A. 

Technical 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

The investment program, which will modernize the road network, does not present any 
24. 
technical  issues.  The  detailed  design  and  cost  estimates  prepared  by  the  World  Bank  have 
been  reviewed  through  value  engineering,  and  cost  estimates  were  updated.  During 
implementation,  climate  change  impacts  will  be  minimized  and  greenhouse  gas  reduction 
measures will be employed. 
 
B. 

Economic and Financial 

An  economic  analysis12 of  the  investment  program  was  conducted  in  accordance  with 
25. 
ADB’s  Guidelines  for  the  Economic  Analysis  of  Projects.13 It  evaluated  the  benefits  with  and 
without  the  investment  program  using  the  highway  development  and  management  model.14 
Road traffic data were updated based on the elasticity of transport demand with respect to GDP. 
The benefits are generated by the road being less congested, faster, shorter, and safer than the 
existing  road.  The  investment  program  is  economically  viable,  with  an  estimated  economic 
internal  rate  of  return  of  17.3%  and  an  estimated  net  present  value  of  $224  million  at  a  12% 
discount rate.  Sensitivity  analysis  confirms  the robustness  of  the  investment  program.  Overall, 
the investment program is justified in social cost–benefit terms. 
 
A  financial  analysis 15 of  the  investment  program  was  carried  out  in  accordance  with 
26. 
ADB’s  Guidelines  on  Financial  Management  and  Analysis  of  Projects.16 Likely  toll  revenues 
were considered in the analysis. The financial internal rate of return is estimated at 6.6%, which 
compares well with the weighted average cost of capital (5.4%), indicating the financial viability 
of the investment program. 
 
C. 

Governance 

27. 
Institutional  capacity.  ARS  staff  involved  in  project  implementation  lacked  knowledge 
about ADB’s guidelines and requirements, which caused initial implementation delays under the 
ongoing  projects.  To  address  this  weakness,  a  program  management  consultant  will  be 
engaged to train and assist ARS in implementing this investment program (paras. 21–22). 
 
28. 
Procurement.  Procurement  plans  will  be  developed  for  each  tranche.  ADB  will  review 
the procurement and consultant selection processes at key stages. The bid documents will be 
based  on  an  independent  engineer’s  cost  estimates  and  international  best  practices.  Optimal 
qualification criteria will be prescribed to maximize competition. The construction period will be 
synchronized with the climate cycle, and bidders will be given at least 8 weeks to prepare bids. 
ADB will monitor procurement activities by ARS and participate in procurement and consultant 
selection.

 Financial management. The financial management assessment of ARS17 highlights the 
29. 
need  for  improvement  in  accounting  systems  and  corporate  governance.  The  program

ARS  received  World  Bank  assistance  to  develop  a  corporate  plan  and  a  manual  on  financial 
reporting  and  procedures.  The  European  Bank  for  Reconstruction  and  Development  assisted 
ARS  in  implementing  the  corporate  plan.  With  external  assistance,  the  capacity  of  ARS  to 
manage  the  implementation  of  externally  funded  projects  improved.  External  independent 
auditing of contracts, accounts, and financial statements will be undertaken to ensure fiduciary 
oversight.  For  the  MFF,  MOT  and  ARS  will  maintain  separate  project  records  and  accounts 
adequate  to  identify  the  (i)  works  and  services  financed  from  the  loan  proceeds,  (ii)  financing 
resources received,  (iii) expenses  incurred  by  the components  of  each  project,  and (iv)  use of 
counterpart  funds.  All  bidding  documents  for  contracts  will  specify  ADB’s  right  to  audit  the 
records and accounts of all contractors, suppliers, consultants, and other service providers. 
 
30. 
Anticorruption measures. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was 
explained to and discussed with the government, MOT, and ARS. Specific policy requirements 
and supplementary measures are described in the facility administration manual (footnote 11). 
 
D. 

Poverty and Social 

The investment program’s direct benefits to the poor are small. However, it will create an 
31. 
enabling environment for poverty reduction,  which includes (i)  lower transport costs, (ii)  additional 
jobs  and  income  from  construction  and  maintenance  of  the  new  motorway,  and  (iii)  better 
access to markets and social services.18 These will generate indirect benefits to the poor. 
 
32. 
The investment program includes some gender elements in terms of improving women’s 
access to markets and services, generating opportunities for skilled women and offering women 
the  chance  to  participate  in  monitoring  the  impact  of  the  investment  program.  The  investment 
program is linked to a pilot project to train women entrepreneurs to scale up their businesses, 
which  will  enable  them  to  benefit  from  better  access  to  markets.19 Improved  access  to  social 
services, economic opportunities, and consumer choices is expected to increase the welfare of 
women,  raise  household  incomes,  enhance  the  achievement  of  the  Millennium  Development 
Goals, and reduce poverty. 
 
33. 
All  projects  financed  under  the  MFF  will  include  appropriate  measures  to  raise  public 
awareness on the potential risks of HIV/AIDS and other sexually transmitted infections, as well 
as  drug  and  human  trafficking.  Contractors  will  be  required  to  take  measures  to  protect 
construction workers from the  risks of HIV/AIDS and other sexually transmitted infections, and 
to give construction workers time to be tested or receive treatment. The supervision consultant 
and  program  management  consultant  will  coordinate  with  the  contractors  and  monitor 
implementation.

 E. 

Safeguards 

Environment. An environmental assessment and review framework20 for the investment 
34. 
program  was  prepared  following  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009)  and  relevant  laws 
and  regulations  in  Azerbaijan.  The  proposed  motorway  is  on  a  new  alignment  with  a  7  km 
section passing through wetlands. The sections to be financed by tranche 1 and 2 are classified 
as  environment  category  A.  The  environmental  impact  assessment  (EIA) 21  reports  were 
prepared in 2007; the World Bank in 2011 prepared an addendum that looked more closely into 
the wetlands and its environmental implications. Based on these reports, a single updated EIA 
was  prepared  that  reflects  compliance  with  the  requirements  of  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement. The EIA recommends specific mitigation measures with regard to motorway design 
and construction and a robust long-term monitoring program. The contracts for the supervision 
consultant, program management consultant, and civil works will include stringent provisions for 
compliance  with  environmental  safeguards.  An  ecological  expert  and  environmental  specialist 
will be engaged to ensure implementation of the environmental management plan. Assurances 
to  mitigate  potential  harm  to the  wetlands  are also included  in the  loan agreement,  framework 
financing agreement, and facility administration manual. 
 
Involuntary  resettlement.  A resettlement framework22 for the investment program was 
35. 
prepared  following  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  and  relevant  laws  and  regulations  in 
Azerbaijan,  and  adopting  the  rehabilitation  strategy  in  the  resettlement  policy  framework.  
LAR activities were substantially completed based on the World Bank’s resettlement plan, which 
the  government  agreed  upon  under  the  earlier  World  Bank-assisted  highway  project.  A  due 
diligence  assessment  confirmed  that  compensation  payments  were  made  following  the 
resettlement  policy  framework  agreed  upon  with  the  World  Bank  and  are  consistent  with  the 
requirements  of  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement.  Outstanding  LAR  activities  include 
compensating the remaining 2% (15 privately owned plots) of households losing portions of their 
agricultural  lands,  paying  compensation  for  affected  municipal  land,  and  providing  additional 
rehabilitation assistance for severely affected and vulnerable households by prioritizing them for 
civil works jobs. Tranche 1 is classified as category A for involuntary resettlement. For tranche 
1, a land acquisition and resettlement plan was prepared to cover the remaining LAR activities, 
including rehabilitation measures and actions to address temporary impacts and emerging LAR 
issues  during  implementation.  Both  the  LAR  framework  and  plan  were  disclosed  on  the  ADB 
website  on  23  July  2012.  Implementation  of  the  LAR  plan  will  be  monitored  internally  and 
externally.  The  program  management  consultant  will  conduct  refresher  training  for  the  land 
acquisition  department  of  ARS  and  respective  district  administrative  staff  on  safeguards,  and 
will monitor LAR-related activities. 
 
36. 
Indigenous peoples. The investment program area does not have any known social or 
cultural  groups  classified  as  indigenous  peoples  under  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement. 
Tranche 1 is classified as category C for indigenous peoples impact.

ASSURANCES 

The  government  and  MOT  have  assured  ADB  that  implementation  of  the  investment
